title: Open data in the physical activity sector
displayTitle: Open data in the physical activity sector
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. Governments, businesses and individuals can use open data to bring about social, economic and environmental benefits.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • What is open data?
  • What is data?
  • What makes data open?
  • Why does the physical activity sector need open data?

title: What is open data?
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data becomes usable when made available in a common, machine-readable format.

Open data must be licensed. Its licence must permit people to use the data in any way they want, including transforming, combining and sharing it with others, even commercially.

title: From raw material to new information and knowledge
displayTitle: From raw material to new information and knowledge
body: Without data we can’t build information, and without information there is no new knowledge.

_items.body:
Data is the raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

Think of data as those locations, images, descriptions, reviews and prices that form the basis of information that can help you plan a holiday, for example.
_items.title: Data

_items.body:
Data becomes information when it is given context.

Following on from the previous example, locations, images, descriptions and prices can all help provide information related to a tourist attraction.

The collection and presentation of data helps to form information.
_items.title: Information

_items.body:
Knowledge is what is derived from information, and personalised for your needs.

Building knowledge is a process of turning information into choices.

Building on the previous example, knowing that no one in your family likes theme parks will help you to decide which places to avoid on holiday, and which would suit your family better.
_items.title: Knowledge

instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

title: What makes data open?
body:
Data is open if anyone can access, use and share it.
There are some simple things to consider when defining openness:

_items.body:
For data to be open, it should have no limitations that prevent it from being used in any particular way.

Anyone should be free to use, modify, combine and share the data – even commercially.
_items.title: Limitations

_items.body:
Open data must be free to use, but this does not mean that it must be free to access.

There is often a cost to creating, maintaining and publishing usable data.

Ideally, any fee for accessing open data should be no more than the reasonable reproduction cost of the unit of data that is requested. 

This reproduction cost tends to be negligible for many datasets.

Live data and big data can incur ongoing costs related to reliable service provision.
_items.title: Cost

_items.body:
Once the user has the data, they are free to use, reuse and redistribute it – even commercially.

Open data is measured by what it can be used for, not by how it is made available.

Aspects like format, structure and machine readability all make data more usable, and should all be carefully considered.

However, these do not make the data more open.
_items.title: Reuse

instruction: Click on the headings to see more.

title: What is open data?
body: Open data is...

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data must also be licensed to allow free usage and be available for commercial use.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data must also be licensed to allow free usage and be available for commercial use.

_items.text: information that we sell to businesses
data that anyone can access, use and share
data that is visible on the Web

title: What is data?
body: Data is...

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Data is the lowest level of raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Data is the lowest level of raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

_items.text: the raw material of information and knowledge.

title: Why does the physical activity sector need open data?
displayTitle: Why does the physical activity sector need open data?
body: What does open data have the power to do?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open data about physical activities can improve services, grow participation and create a healthier population.

_feedback.correct:
That's right.

Open data about physical activities can improve services, grow participation and create a healthier population.

_items.text: Improve services, grow participation and create a healthier population

title: What makes data open?
body: Open data should be...

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

If something restricts the free use of the data, such as a non-commercial restriction, then this would not qualify as being open data.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

If something restricts the free use of the data, such as a non-commercial restriction, then this would not qualify as being open data.

_items.text: free from restrictions for its use

title: Open data in the physical activity sector
displayTitle: Open data in the physical activity sector
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data is a raw material for the digital age but, unlike coal, timber or diamonds, it can be used by anyone and everyone at the same time.

Any restrictions imposed on the use of open data will limit its potential for creating new value.

Open data can bring diverse benefits to the physical activity sector. It has the power to help improve services, grow participation and create a healthier population. Open data can help get more people active.

Ready to make a difference? In the next module, we will explore ways that open data could create impact for the physical activity sector.

Next module

title: Why does the physical activity sector need open data?
displayTitle: Why does the physical activity sector need open data?
body:
At any one time around 25% of people in England are inactive.

Among the barriers they face, both emotional and practical, is a lack of information on what is available to them. 

Publishing data openly has the power to help improve services, grow participation and therefore create a healthier population. Open data can help get more people active.
instruction: Click on the headings to see more.

_items.body:
By publishing quality open data, providers will make it easier for websites and apps to use it and create information that people can act on.

Enabling people to easily find and book activities will help increase participation.  

This will improve user satisfaction and ultimately create a better experience for people.

The third module in this set focuses on how to prioritise which data to publish openly.
_items.title: Improving the users' experience

_items.body:
Open data is driving a new wave of innovative apps, websites and products. By publishing data openly, activity providers and national bodies can help stimulate new ideas and ways for getting people active.

Knowing the services that competing providers offer can also help activity providers to refine their own offerings and attract more customers.
_items.title: Creating innovation in the sector

_items.body:
The more data about activities is openly available, the more people are likely to find out about and attend those activities.

Opening up data can help increase both the number and the variety of participants, and boost revenue for activity providers.

Open data can also improve efficiency for activity providers, since by using it they can avoid repeat data collection. 

The next module further explores the impact of open data for the physical activity sector.
_items.title: Benefiting activity providers

title: Are you ready for open physical activity data?
displayTitle: Are you ready for open physical activity data?
body: There are four helpful things to remember when thinking about opening your data. Can you remember them?

title: Ready to create impact?
body:
Open data has the power to help grow economies, transform societies and increase efficiency.

Physical activity providers can use open data to get more people involved, create better experiences for participants and create new products and services that will help more people get active. 

Ready to get hands on? In the next module we'll explore how to prioritise which physical activity data to publish openly.

Previous module Next module

title: Creating impact from open data
body:
Physical activity providers can use open data to get more people involved, create better experiences for participants and run their organisations more efficiently. 

In this module, we will explore how the public sector, businesses and individuals in other sectors are already using open data to create impact and we will explore the potential that open data could have for the physical activity sector.

In this module, we’ll explore the following:

  • Opportunities for the public sector 
  • Innovation and growth in business
  • Changing society

title: Changing society
body: Open data is changing the way society works, by unlocking new social value and enabling data-driven decisions across a wide range of sectors. In the physical activity sector, this means getting more people active.
instruction: Click the headings to explore further

_items.body:
In the physical activity sector, open data can support behaviour change and get more people active

For someone who hasn't done any physical activity since school, data can answer the practical questions and help put them at ease - what equipment is provided and what do they need to bring? What should they wear? What level of fitness is expected?

For someone who travels regularly for work, being presented with suggested options for activities based on their calendar location information, dates, and their preferred activity types would enable them to continue to be active, despite a busy schedule.

Whatever stage someone is at with their physical activity, open data can help. Module 3 explores in more detail how publishing data openly can help get more people active.
_items.title: Changing behaviour
Improving health and wellbeing
_items.body:
Knowing what physical activities opportunities are available can help doctors recommend activities to their patients that are beneficial for their health.

For individuals, social prescribing can be used to connect them with organisations and activities in their community.  Rather than prescribing medicine, local GPs and other local agencies could, for example, prescribe joining a local running club for an individual suffering from loneliness or depression.

_items.title: Meeting digital expectations
_items.body:
Many opportunities to do physical activity are hidden away in old old-fashioned websites, social media groups, PDFs or printed flyers.

Publishing this data openly in a standardised format enables consumers to easily discover what activities are available to them.

To find the nearest available tennis court, users are likely to search using a mapping application, like Google maps. However this is not the only way users expect to be able to find activities. Open data can enable many different services to provide directory listings to your services. 

Open data released by Transport for London is now used in over 800 mobile applications (including Google Maps).

These apps meet the digital expectations of all types of users, from the occasional traveller, to daily commuters and those who require assistance with their journeys.

Find out more about data standards for the physical activity sector.

title: Are you ready to create impact from open data?
displayTitle: Are you ready to create impact from open data?
body: There are lots of valuable examples of open data initiatives bringing social, economic and environmental benefits. Are you ready to join the open data movement?

title: Choosing the right data to publish
displayTitle: Choosing the right data to publish
body:
Any physical activity dataset can be made open provided it does not contain personal data or sensitive information.

Your organisation needs to prioritise data that will make the greatest impact both for your and your potential users, because data takes time to clean, publish and promote.

In the next module, we look at why you should make your data useful and usable before you publish it and how to do that. 

Previous module Next module

title: What types of data are opportunity data?
displayTitle: What types of data are opportunity data?
body: Examples of opportunity data are...
instruction: Choose all that apply, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Popularity, ease and distance from transport

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Location, activity, cost, difficulty, fitness level, fun-factor, popularity, ease and distance are all examples of opportunity data.

Staff wages are not a type of opportunity data. Moreover, wage data is personal data and therefore should not be made open without explicit permission of those involved and, in most cases, suitable anonymisation.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Location, activity, cost, difficulty, fitness level, fun-factor, popularity, ease and distance are all examples of opportunity data.


Staff wages are not a type of opportunity data. Moreover, wage data is personal data and therefore should not be made open without explicit permission of those involved and, in most cases, suitable anonymisation.

title: Why is opportunity data a good place to start?
displayTitle: Why is opportunity data a good place to start?
body: You should prioritise opportunity data to publish openly, because...

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Opportunity data is a good place to start when publishing open data, because it helps to meet the shared goal of getting more people active.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Opportunity data is a good place to start when publishing open data, because it helps to meet the shared goal of getting more people active.

_items.text: it is the data that is most relevant to consumers and the most likely to get them active
providers will have access to all participants’ personal data

title: What types of data are opportunity data?
displayTitle: What types of data are opportunity data?

title: Where do I start?
body: A good place to start when prioritising which data to publish openly is...

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The most successful open data publications align the goals of the data providers with the goals of users. The more closely aligned the goals are, the more successful the publication tends to be.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

The most successful open data publications align the goals of the data providers with the goals of users. The more closely aligned the goals are, the more successful the publication tends to be.

_items.text: identifying the shared goals of the data provider and the data user

_items.body: What type of activity is this? For example, yoga, hockey or fencing.
_items.title: What it is

_items.body:
The location where the activity takes place or the address of the activity provider.

There may be more than one location, such as a start and an end location for an event or walking route.
_items.title: Where it is

_items.body:
The time and date when the activity would take place. This could be over a broad range (e.g. this weekend), or a specific time (e.g. 6pm on Wednesday).

There may be multiple times; for example cycle rides may have a gathering time and a ride time, or the event might be one off or recurring.
_items.title: When it is

_items.body: Is the activity suitable for beginners or targeted at people with more experience? Are there restrictions, such as age group, accessibility, or gender?
_items.title: Who it's for

_items.body:
Is the activity free, does it require membership or can I make a one-off payment? 

Are there additional costs such as lockers or equipment hire?
_items.title: How much

_items.body: Do I need to wear something specific or bring any safety equipment? Do I need to have a qualification to do this activity?
_items.title: Requirements

_items.body:
How do users get in contact with the provider? This might include an email address, phone number or a website address. 

Be careful to check that the organiser has given permission for these details to be shared, as details such as individual names, phone numbers and email addresses are personal data.
_items.title: How to get in contact

title: Are you ready to prioritise your data for publishing openly?
displayTitle: Are you ready to prioritise your data for publishing openly?

title: Prioritising data to publish openly
body:
There are many physical activity datasets that can be published as open data. Prioritising which data to publish openly first can be difficult. Your organisation needs to prioritise data that will have the greatest impact both for you and your users, because data takes time to clean, publish and promote.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • Where do I start?
  • Why is 'opportunity data' a good place to start?
  • What types of data are 'opportunity data'?

title: Technical considerations
body: There are three technical considerations as part of the standards for publishing open data, one of which is...

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data. The format in which the data is published in, the structure of the data and the channels through which the data is available.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data. The format in which the data is published in, the structure of the data and the channels through which the data is available.

_items.text: whether it can it be used on a computer
whether it takes up much bandwidth
what format the open data is published in

title: Summary
body:
For consumers, an open ecosystem is a clear route that enables easier access to a wider range of opportunities to get active.

The transport sector has proven that an open ecosystem can work to the benefit of all parties. 

Opening up key data encourages competition and innovation by data users who in turn now have access to large amounts of previously unavailable data.

What will you do next?

Previous module Main menu

title: Quality open data
body:
Publishing open opportunity data can bring you a range of benefits, from more people using your facilities to better exposure for your activities online. But for you and your users to enjoy those benefits, your open opportunity data needs to be of a good enough quality to use. This module looks at what quality data is and how you can apply some simple checks to minimise problems.

Be aware that fixing problems with your data may take longer than you think. Ensuring your open opportunity data is good quality data will save substantial time in the long-run and make your data much more useful to app developers and ultimately anyone who wants to take part in your activities.

Having prepared your data, in the next module we will explore the different degrees of openness, what the future looks like and the journey to get there.

Previous module Next module

title: What do we mean by 'open data quality'?
displayTitle: What do we mean by 'open data quality'?
body:
Open data is most useful when it is easy to understand and simple to use. If your data is messy, people will have trouble using it. This problem is worse when the 'person' using it isn't a person at all but a software programme. If you give messy data to an app or a map, it won't display properly, which means no one can use it effectively.

When we talk about open data quality, we mean that the data can be understood by a person and used by software like apps and maps. The more people that have access to your data – either directly, or via an app or a map – the more people will interact with the services you provide as their consumer needs are being met.

title: Where can I get help to make sure my data is good quality?
displayTitle: Where can I get help to make sure my data is good quality?
body:
The quality of your open opportunity data is important, however understanding what quality open opportunity data is to your audience is also important.


To help you understand the quality of your open opportunity data, there are some basic things you should consider. Not all of these are straightforward and some might require you to check with your technical team or your booking system provider. However, answering them will give you a clear picture of whether your open opportunity data meets quality standards. Browse the categories below to learn about the key questions you need to ask.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.body:
Legal requirements

Open data must be released under an open licence. Find out more about licensing in this module.

In addition to the open licence, there are three legal requirements that need to be considered. You must:

  • Protect sensitive information like personal data.
  • Preserve the rights of data owners.
  • Promote correct use of the data.
_items.title: Legal requirements

_items.body:
It is important that open data can be found and relied upon by users.

This means that open data publishers must:

  • Link to the data from their website, rather than just publishing information in PDFs.
  • Update the data regularly if it changes.
  • Commit to continue to make the data openly available.
_items.title: Practical requirements

_items.body:
There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data:

  • The channels through which the data is available.
  • The format in which the data is published.
  • The structure of the data.

Putting any sort of data on a website is a good start, as this is the best channel.

Putting that data out there as text in a PDF is not a very useable format (you can find out more about data formats in this eLearning module). 

Structuring the data inside a spreadsheet (Excel or equivalent) and linking this spreadsheet from the website is better.
_items.title: Technical requirements

_items.body:
For data use to be sustainable, it is important to have an engaged community of users. The best datasets have:

  • Active support channels.
  • Discussion groups and forums.
  • Published how-to guides on working with the data.
_items.title: Social requirements

title: How to make your open opportunity data useful
displayTitle: How to make your open opportunity data useful
body:
Publishing open opportunity data can bring you a range of benefits, from more people using your facilities to better exposure for your activities online. But for you and your users to both enjoy those benefits, your open opportunity data needs to be of a good enough quality to use.

  • What do we mean by 'open data quality'?
  • Where can I get help to make sure my data is good quality?
  • How can I quickly and easily improve my open opportunity data quality?

title: How can I quickly and easily improve my data quality?
displayTitle: How can I quickly and easily improve my data quality?
body:
Errors and inconsistencies often occur in data. They are the main barrier to producing good quality data. Common errors include duplicate entries, missing data, inconsistent use of abbreviations and spelling mistakes. 

OpenActive have created a guide to improving your data quality.  This guide is for anyone who manages data entry for sports and physical activities, to help you make the most of OpenActive.  You might work in the head office for a large gym group, or you might be an individual instructor, promoting your own classes - it’s for everyone.

title: What are the badges that indicate data quality?
displayTitle: What are the badges that indicate data quality?
body: Badges are often added to open data to demonstrate their quality. These badges are designed to give users of the data – such as app developers – some certainty about its quality and usefulness. There are two key badges of quality for open data:

_items.body:
The '5 Stars of linked open data' indicate that a dataset meets the basic legal definition of open and has some technical characteristics that make it useful for others.

The 5 Stars were developed by inventor of the Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee, in 2001. The 5 Stars make recommendations for the format and structure of the data.
_items.title: 5 Stars

_items.body:
The Open Data Institute's Open Data Certificate badge indicates that a dataset meets basic practical, social, legal and technical guidelines.

The badge is a self-assessment questionnaire for publishers to assess and benchmark the full usability of a dataset.  Take me to the ODI Open Data Certificate site.
_items.title: ODI Open Data Certificates

title: Are you ready to ensure quality open data?
displayTitle: Are you ready to ensure quality open data?

title: Opportunities for the public sector
body: The public sector benefits from open data initiatives in many ways:
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.body:
To help new data-driven businesses to develop and existing ones to grow, the public sector needs to publish key datasets.

It also needs to support data infrastructure that connects data with those who use it.

In return, the public sector can reap the benefits of a growing data economy. For example, in Finland, SMEs with access to open data grew 15% faster than those without.

Take me to the Finnish case study
_items.title: Supporting growing economies

_items.body:
Making detailed open data available is essential to improving service delivery for businesses and individuals.

The Environment Agency released 1,500 datasets, driven by its initiative #opendefra.

As part of this, the open LIDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) data has helped optimise rooftop solar-cell installation. Open flood data made it possible for The Red Cross to build an app combining it with Met Office weather warnings to issue real-time alerts.

In the transport sector, Transport for London, released their travel data and enabled developers to provide consumer-friendly services, helping customers to save an estimated £58m worth of saved time per year (pdf).
_items.title: Improved service delivery
Efficiency savings
_items.body:
By releasing open data on its public transport, the city of San Francisco has reduced its number of incoming telephone queries by around 22%, which has generated annual savings of more than $1m.

The startup Prescribing Analytics – a joint venture between NHS doctors and technologists – used open data to identify a £200m per year saving for the NHS if they were to switch to own-brand statins and utilise more efficient delivery routes.

title: Innovation and growth in businesses
body:
Open data is supporting innovation and growth by revealing opportunities for businesses large and small to build new services, identify savings and improve operations.

In Paris, café owners are using open data to attract tourists to the city's most affordable coffees, while in Iceland farmers are using open data about the quality of their lambs to attract new customers.

UK startup CityMapper joined up available transport data to improve the ways in which citizens could travel. Since its inception in 2011, CityMapper has received $50m in funding and has expanded to over 50 cities.

Open data stimulates innovation by removing barriers to access, use and shareability of data.

title: Opportunities for the public sector
body: Open data awareness is now...

_incorrect.final:

A new generation across the world has grown to expect a digitally literate and engaged public sector.

_feedback.correct:

A new generation across the world has grown to expect a digitally literate and engaged public sector.

_items.text: a little more important than it used to be

title: Changing society
body: One benefit of having open physical activity data is that...

_incorrect.final:

Open physical activity data makes it easier to find, access and compare activities, facilities and classes.

_feedback.correct:

_items.text: people will have to travel further to do physical activities

title: Improving quality
body: Which of the following are errors in open opportunity data that require cleaning?
instruction: Choose three answers and click Submit

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Missing postcodes, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed to make sure your open opportunity data is usable. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being unclean.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Missing postcodes, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed to make sure your open opportunity data is usable. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being unclean.

title: Where do I start?
body:
The first thing to think about is what you are trying to achieve. What is your end-goal for publishing your data openly?

Next, think about your potential data users. What are their goals? How would your data help them to achieve their goals?

The most successful open data publications align the goals of the data providers with the data users. It's rare that everyone starts out with identical goals, so look for areas where those goals overlap. The more closely aligned the goals are, the more successful the publication tends to be.

The physical activity sector is a great example of where the goal of an activity provider can align with that of data users. Activity providers want more people to be active through using their services, and data users want to help people find appropriate activities that meet their needs.

title: Why is opportunity data a good place to start?
displayTitle: Why is opportunity data a good place to start?
body:
Across the physical activity sector, a key blocker to increasing participation is helping people understand what, when and where physical activity sessions happen. This type of data is known as opportunity data.  

Publishing opportunity data as open data will help achieve the shared goal of getting more people active. It takes relatively low effort for relatively high rewards.
instruction: Click on the headings to explore further

_items.body:
Publishing opportunity data as open data takes relatively low effort. It is data that activity providers tend to collect as part of their normal business activities (see below for examples of opportunity data).

Opportunity data does not include personal data, unless permitted by the provider. Personal data is data related to an identified or identifiable individual. It is protected by the Data Protection Act and should not normally be published by an organisation without suitable anonymisation.  

Opportunity data may include personal data if permitted by the provider, for example the contact details to book a yoga class or community football pitch.
_items.title: Low effort

_items.body:
Open opportunity data can be turned into useful information and enable participants to easily find activities that match their needs.

It can drive competition between providers, help improve services, and increase reach and revenue. 

Professionals can use opportunity data to make informed recommendations to their clients.

Open opportunity data can also enable innovation across sectors as new businesses and providers identify gaps in the market.

Module 2 explores the impact of open data in different sectors in more detail.

However, in order for open opportunity data to be beneficial it needs to be accurate, consistent and up to date. Module 4 explores how you can make your data useful.
_items.title: High reward

title: What types of data are opportunity data?
displayTitle: What types of data are opportunity data?
body:
Opportunity data informs consumers about what, where and when activities are happening. It can also include the cost of accessing that activity.

Examples could include details about available badminton courts, the costs of yoga classes or swimming pool timetables. Opportunity data does not include personal data unless permitted by the provider, for example, the contact details to book a yoga class or community football pitch.

The headings below explore the different types of data that make up opportunity data.
instruction: Click on the headings to explore further

title: The potential futures of physical activity data
displayTitle: The potential futures of physical activity data
body:
Not all data is open data, and nor should it be. When working with data, it is important to consider the appropriate level of openness for it.

In this module, we'll learn about three different types, or 'futures', that data can have: open, shared and closed. We'll explore what each of these mean and how they apply to data about physical activity. We'll also look at how to classify your data and challenges that may come with making data more open.

This module introduces: 

  • Open, shared and closed data
  • Why we need three data futures
  • Choosing a future for physical activity data
  • The process of choosing a data future
  • Challenges of achieving an open future

title: Open, shared, closed data
body:
Data is the raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived. This raw material covers a wide variety of things – from things like cinema screenings and train times to a company's financials or an individual's medical history.

The Open Data Institute's Data Spectrum can help to classify data as open, shared or closed.

_items.body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. Governments and organisations have opened up access to data such as weather records, earthquake monitoring, and even particle physics, allowing others to use this data and discover new solutions for the benefit of all.

Find out more about open data and the physical activity sector.
_items.title: Open data

_items.body: Shared data is data that is shared with a specific group of people, for a specific purpose. It is a broad term that covers a huge amount of the data that is collected everyday. Your supermarket shopping habits and the electoral register are just two examples of shared data.
_items.title: Shared data

_items.body: Closed data is data that only individuals or people inside a single organisation can see. There are good reasons why this data is closed, and why we don’t want anyone to be able to access and use it however they like. Such data includes personal and company email.
_items.title: Closed data

title: Open / Shared / Closed: The world of data
displayTitle: Open / Shared / Closed: The world of data
body: The world of data is starting to be defined by three different types of data: open, shared and closed. Find out more about each in this short video.

title: Why we need open, shared and closed data
displayTitle: Why we need open, shared and closed data
body: Before we can choose the right 'future' for data (closed, shared or open), we need to explore why the different data types all play an important role in the world of data.

_items.title: Open
_items.body:
An open data future is one where data is available for anyone to access, use and share.

An open data future maximises innovation and opportunities for unexpected benefit. 

Without open data, Citymapper and Google Maps would not know the time of the next bus.

The release of the Light Imaging, Detection, And Ranging (LIDAR) data from the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (DEFRA) led to gamers creating virtual worlds in Minecraft. This allows young children to explore their cities and towns (and even rebuild them) in a game.

In a shared data future, data is released to a specific group of people. Sometimes data is shared for a specific purpose only.

Sharing medical records and research with specific companies is critical to help improve healthcare. However, this data is often quite sensitive and in most cases cannot be shared widely.

Data sharing has the advantage of allowing a slightly wider group of people to use and benefit from the data, whilst also retaining some control and limiting the use of sensitive data.
_items.title: Shared

_items.body:
A closed data future is one where data remains secure in individual organisations. Sometimes only a handful of named individuals will have access to the data.

Examples of this include national security data, confidential business secrets, or your employment record with human resources.

Closed data is necessary to protect the rights of individuals and the intellectual capital of organisations.

However, not all data needs to be closed. It can be useful to look at data from a different angle, to justify why it should be closed, instead of justifying why it should be open. This approach is called 'open by default.'
_items.title: Closed

title: Choosing a future for physical activity data
displayTitle: Choosing a future for physical activity data
body:
Three common types of data in the physical activity sector are opportunity data, participation data and people data.

Explore where each sits on the spectrum below and discover how placing data is not always straightforward.

_items.body:
Across the physical activity sector, a key blocker to increasing participation is helping people understand what, when and where physical activity sessions happen. This type of data is known as opportunity data.  

Publishing opportunity data as open data will help to achieve the shared goal of getting more people active. It takes low effort for high rewards. 

The main blockers to the open publication of opportunity data are likely to be 1) contractual obligations that prevent the data being shared more openly, 2) mistrust in the data use and feeling of loss of control, and 3) lack of technical confidence and the resources to open the data.
_items.title: Opportunity data
Participation data
_items.body:
Participation data links activities to people, detailing what people have taken part in, where and when. While a lot of this data might be highly personal and therefore should remain closed (or shared), this is not always the case.

For example, data about individual rankings in an Olympic 400m will have fewer privacy and usage concerns than data about participants at a weekly children’s swimming club.

The number of people attending each session could also help to inform people when choosing which session to attend. This is a service that Google already provides with shops.

Within the physical activity sector, there are a number of areas where data about people may be gathered. These could include details about people who attend events, information about coaches and trainers that may run sessions, or contact details for individuals to discuss activities. There are different considerations and levels of sensitivity around each of these, and typically data about people is much less likely to be fully open.
_items.title: People data

title: The challenges of an open future
displayTitle: The challenges of an open future
body: Moving to an open data future is not without its challenges. Below, we explore some of the common challenges and ways that you can overcome them.

_items.title: Culture change and collaboration
_items.body:
One of the biggest challenges facing an open data future is changing your culture to be more open or collaborative.

The culture of data sharing is growing, but there is still a lot of mistrust. Many people still believe that data sharing is abnormal, unnecessary or could cause them problems.

Such challenges can be overcome through advocating the benefits, increasing data literacy and top-down support for open practices. Try sharing this eLearning for a start.

Open data needs to support or improve an organisation's business model.

Open data has also been proven to help create new models and opportunities that were not previously available.

In the next module, we will explore how data changes a business and the potential that new models can bring.
_items.title: Strategy and business plans
Standards
_items.body:
Using common and open standards for your open data can help you to maximise its impact.

Standards help you to speak the same language as others and be able to compete in the market. It will ensure that all of the sector's open data is standardised, regardless of where it comes from. This will make it easier to compare and use.

OpenActive standards, including the modelling opportunity standard and the open booking standard, have been created in collaboration with the community and are now being adopted by the sector.

For some organisations and individuals, limited resources and finding the capacity to publish open data is a challenge. Such organisations have a valid concern about whether they’ll be able to release and maintain open data. 

Data providers should look at prioritising which data they can publish openly. As the sector’s relationship with data matures, more tools and platforms will emerge to reduce friction.

Module 3 looks at prioritising which data to publish openly.
_items.title: Cost and prioritisation

title: Choosing your data future
body: There are six questions to ask yourself when choosing whether to make an individual dataset open, shared or closed. Explore these in more detail below.

_items.body:
Is the dataset that you are looking at currently open, shared or closed?

It can be helpful to start by mapping the datasets that you have on the Data Spectrum. Remember to look at who is currently permitted to use the data, as data is only open if made available under an open licence. You may find in this process that you have data that is publicly accessible but is not under an open licence.

You also might find you are already publishing open data without realising it.
_items.title: 1) Where is the dataset now?

_items.body:
Having worked out where your datasets currently sit, look back over each and identify those that should be moved.

At this early stage, try not to focus too much on the specifics of how to move each. Instead, try to identify those that are closed but could be shared or open, or are shared but could be open.

Equally important is to identify datasets that are currently open or shared but should be closed because they contain personal or sensitive data.
_items.title: 2) Where should each dataset be?

_items.body:
At this stage, it is important to think about the benefits and blockers.

What are the benefits for your business, for your customers, for those who may want to innovate with your data, for other use cases outside of your industry, and for society as a whole?

You should also think about potential blockers, whether any changes are needed to your organisation's way of working, strategy or business plan, and whether you have the resources to make the data available (and maintain it).
_items.title: 3) What are the pros and cons?

_items.body:
Before continuing, you should double check that the datasets you've listed are yours to publish or that you have their provider's permission to move them along the Data Spectrum.

If you aren't currently permitted to move the data along the spectrum, then it might be worth asking the provider and outlining the benefits to them.
_items.title: 4) Third party ownership and rights?
5) How can each dataset be moved?
_items.body:
At this stage, we need to explore the finer detail of how we can move datasets along the spectrum.

It may be a case of licensing the dataset correctly. Alternatively, the dataset may need anonymising before it can be made openly available.

You can find out more about anonymisation in this online guide, or by getting in touch with the UK Anonymisation Network (UKAN).

_items.title: 6) What next?
_items.body:
The last question to ask yourself is what the next steps are.

Identifying quick wins – short-term activities that will demonstrate progress – is useful in getting support from others.

There may be one or two datasets that are easier to open than others. It might be straightforward to move a dataset from closed to shared, with the eventual goal of releasing it openly.

It may be worth sharing your spectrum with your community and engage them in the discussion. The OpenActive project is a great place to start, so why not get in touch?

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Ready to choose your future?
body: Are you ready to choose the right future for your data?

title: Q: Three data futures
body: What are the three data futures?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The three data futures are open, shared and closed.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

The three data futures are open, shared and closed.

title: Q: Match data to the right future
displayTitle: Match data to the right future
body: Can you match the datasets below to their best potential future?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Yoga instructors’ home addresses should most likely be closed, attendees in a dance class may be shared, and table-tennis table locations would be valuable open data.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Yoga instructors’ home addresses should most likely be closed, attendees in a dance class may be shared, and table-tennis table locations would be valuable open data.

title: Q: Choosing your data future
body: Which of the following are part of the process of choosing your data future?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

As part of the process, you should identify where datasets are now, check your rights to change the data future and consider the pros and cons of doing so.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

As part of the process, you should identify where datasets are now, check your rights to change the data future and consider the pros and cons of doing so.

_items.text: Thinking about the pros and cons

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Q: Challenges of achieving an open future
displayTitle: Challenges of achieving an open future
body: There are a number of potential challenges to make when deciding whether to open data. Some of these are a potential lack of collaboration and the need for culture change in an organisation. Select a way in which these can be overcome:

_items.text: Advocating the benefits, and increasing data literacy and top-down support
Waiting for everyone else to release data openly first
Forming individual relationships between app developers and activity providers

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Cultural challenges can be overcome through advocating the benefits, increasing data literacy and ensuring top-down support for open practices.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Cultural challenges can be overcome through advocating the benefits, increasing data literacy and ensuring top-down support for open practices.

title: Summary
displayTitle: The potential futures of physical activity data
body:
There are three futures for data, open, shared and closed. 

When working with data, it is important to consider the appropriate level of openness, taking into consideration both the data's type and its potential impact. 

While some data – including personal data – should be closed, there is also a huge opportunity for open data to provide both direct and indirect benefits. 

In the physical activity sector, opening up opportunity data has the potential to increase the number of people participating in activities.

There are challenges to be overcome still, one of the main ones being the potential change to existing business models. The next module looks at these challenges in more detail, along with potential solutions.

Previous module Next module

title: Business in an open data led physical activity sector
displayTitle: Business in an open data led physical activity sector
body:
'How will open data affect my business?' is a common question that arises.

In this module, we look at the impact an open future will have on businesses within the physical activity sector.

This module looks at the following:

  • The value of an open ecosystem
  • The value of open for businesses
  • The open ecosystem in action
  • Taking action
  • The future

title: The value of open to businesses
displayTitle: The value of open to businesses
body: The key point tipping point of businesses in the activity space comes where opening up data is more beneficial than keeping it closed. The value comes from the service provided, not from the transaction of data. Examine how this change to a service model affects revenue, costs and brand below.

_items.title: Increased revenue
_items.body:
With greater access to data, organisations are able to increase their revenue in different ways.

Activity providers can:

  • Reach greater numbers and types of customers via new and existing channels.
  • Fill quiet times through different ways of promotion.

Data users can:

  • Explore opportunities for innovation that were previously difficult due to a lack of access to data.
  • Gain first-mover advantage and access to new markets without needing commercial agreements.

_items.title: Reduced costs
_items.body:
Providing greater freedom around the access and use of data will help to reduce costs over the longer term.

Activity providers can:

  • Remove the burden of managing individual data-sharing agreements.
  • Reduce the costs of having to create tools and products on top of data – share the load with external innovators for mutual benefits.
  • Simplify data management and sharing through access to a greater number of third-party options.

Data users can:

  • Access data directly without having to negotiate individually.
  • Ensure the consistency of open data thanks to common standards.
  • Explore greater opportunities for data re-use and sales in new markets.

_items.title: Brand and meeting business goals
_items.body:
In a sector that is more open by default, companies can gain benefits that will help them meet their business goals.

Data users can:

  • Build new partnerships.
  • Improve the perception and awareness of both their brand and the activity providers brand.
  • Open up more opportunities for consumption of physical activities.

title: Are you ready to lead in an open ecosystem?
displayTitle: Are you ready to lead in an open ecosystem?

title: Q: Where is the value in an open ecosystem?
displayTitle: Where is the value in an open ecosystem?
body: Where is the value in an open ecosystem?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

An open ecosystem can help increase revenue, reduce costs and drive efficiency and enhance reputation.

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

An open ecosystem can help increase revenue, reduce costs and drive efficiency and enhance reputation.

_items.text: Help one organisation monopolise the market

title: Q: Taking action – activity providers
body: What should activity providers look to do in order to take advantage of an open ecosystem?

_items.text: Establish exclusivity agreements with service providers for use of opportunity data
Understand which data users are best placed to consume and display their open opportunity data

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

Data users and platform providers help connect activity providers to consumers through the management and use of data. Therefore, their key role is to create services for consumers and activity providers.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Data users and platform providers help connect activity providers to consumers through the management and use of data. Therefore, their key role is to create services for consumers and activity providers.
_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure?

Data users and platform providers help connect activity providers to consumers through the management and use of data. Therefore, their key role is to create services for consumers and activity providers

title: Q: Taking action - Data users
body: What should data users look to do in order to take advantage of an open ecosystem?

_items.text: Support the OpenActive standards and consume and display open data
Scrape sports data from the web

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Data users should support the OpenActive standards for your data and help activity providers promote their opportunities via open data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Data users should support the OpenActive standards for your data and help activity providers promote their opportunities via open data.

title: Continuing your open data journey
body:
You've come to the end of this eLearning module, but it's not the end of your open data journey.

Got some data you want to publish? Get in touch

Interested in shaping the open data standards for the physical activity sector? Join the W3C community group.

Want to learn more? Take a look at what's out there for you to learn.

title: Open ecosystem in action
body:
The OpenActive blog contains a number of different case studies showcasing how open data is benefitting organisations in the sport and physical activity sector, from local authorities to system providers.

Highlights include:

How OpenActive can help local authorities get more people active

Using open data to encourage sports participation in later life

How OpenActive functionality helps reach larger audiences

title: Taking action – activity providers
body: Explore what is required of activity providers and what they gain from opening their data.

_items.title: What to do
_items.body: The primary action for activity providers is to open your opportunity data. See the OpenActive website for how to do this.

_items.title: What you gain
_items.body: As with Transport for London (TfL), open data has driven innovation which has allowed an ecosystem of services and applications to emerge naturally. User needs have been fulfilled without the data owner needing to be involved. To increase participation in your activities with little or no expenditure, open data is the way to go.

title: Taking action – Data users
body: Explore what actions data users can take in order to gain the most in an open ecosystem.

_items.title: What to do
_items.body: Support the standards and help activity providers promote their opportunities via open data. Encourage activity providers to use your service to get their opportunity data out there. Develop your USP in the sector using open data to open new markets and locations.

Interoperability with everyone also publishing data conforming to the standard. This enables the easier use of this data to help you open up new markets without the need for complex commercial agreements.

It also helps you to compete with others to grow your business and be the provider of choice. If activity providers increase turnover as a result of more people engaging in activities, it is likely they will need more services for these people. Everyone wins.
_items.title: What you gain

title: Looking to the future
body:
What will the future bring for the physical activity sector with open opportunity data? Once again, we can look to other sectors for the answer. In the entertainment sector, websites like ODEON provide an open API that gives developers access to film times. Integration with Apple and Google products allows you to book tickets for movie screenings from your watch. Companies like Citymapper provide unrivalled access to advanced transport data for cities that have open data. OpenTable offers an API for restaurant table bookings.

The future of opportunity data seems a clear one. Open data will enable the integration with key platforms such that one day soon you will be able to book an activity with your favourite voice-activated service.

'OK Google, tell Siri to ask Alexa to book me a badminton court tonight at 7pm.'

With open data, you don't have to be bound by any one service. Instead, you can use them all.

title: The value of an open ecosystem
displayTitle: The value of an open ecosystem
body: Open data provides the opportunity for much wider collaboration in order to get more people involved in physical activity. Explore how an open ecosystem can be built, upon which everyone can operate a service, below.

_items.title: Data as roads
_items.body:
Much like roads help us get to a location, open opportunity data can help us engage in sport and physical activity.

However, not everyone uses one road to get to a location, and not everyone uses the roads in the same way. 

Some people will walk, some will drive and some take a bus. People have a choice of services which all use the same infrastructure: roads.

_items.title: Infinite services on open data roads
_items.body:
Unlike roads, open data can be used by everyone at the same time. Data is infinite, meaning that multiple use doesn't degrade the service for others.

Unlike roads, which only support certain types of service provider (you can't run a train, boat or tram on a road), open data can be used for a variety of imaginative purposes. 

A key example of this is Transport for London (TFL), whose open data is now used by over 600 travel applications that give everyone – regardless of nationality (language), disability or technical capability – access to the right information at the right time. This means that more people can use the services that TfL provides, or use the data to play games.
_items.strapline: Infinite services on open data roads

_items.title: The role of data users
_items.body:
Data users give consumers choice. Just like with roads, some people will choose the bus, or to hire a bike.

Data users play a key role in reaching different audiences and providing value-added services built on top of their own data and that of others.

Like with the apps which consume the TfL open data, a competitive market will emerge, however, there are also a huge amount of unique selling points for each solution, meaning that each coexists while still consuming the same source data.

Activity providers, like TfL, are the winners in this situation.

Being able to maximise the use of their data unlocks opportunities for everyone to engage in their activities.

Activity providers should help ensure everyone is able to use their open data and build services.
_items.title: The role of activity providers

title: Q: The value of an open ecosystem
displayTitle: The value of an open ecosystem
body: In an open ecosystem, data can be...
instruction: Select your answer and then click 'submit'

_items.text: used by everyone to create new services

_feedback.correct:
That's right! 

Open data is like roads that anyone can use and build new services on. However, unlike roads, which only support certain types of data user (you can't run a train, boat or tram on a road), open data can be used for many purposes.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Open data is like roads which anyone can use and build new services on. However, unlike roads, which only support certain types of data users (you can't run a train, boat or tram on a road), open data can be used for many purposes.

title: Badges that indicate quality
body: The Open Data Institute advocates the use of its own quality marque, known as...

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The Open Data Institute has developed Open Data Certificates which include practical and social requirements alongside in-depth legal and technical guidelines to consider when publishing open data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The Open Data Institute has developed Open Data Certificates which include practical and social requirements alongside in-depth legal and technical guidelines to consider when publishing open data.

title: What makes open data useable?
body: Open data becomes useable when...

_items.text: it is imported into a common system
a person can understand it, software like apps and maps can use it and it is made available under an open licence

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open data becomes usable when a person can understand it, software like apps and maps can use it and it is made available under an open licence.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Open data becomes usable when a human can understand it, machines can manipulate it and it is made available under an open licence.
